results.title: Capability Brown
results.creator_credit: D.C. Chipperfield and Ransomes Film Unit
results.brief_description: The work of Lancelot Brown (1716-1793), the founder of the English style of landscape gardening, whose pioneering was, to a great extent, responsible for the very shape of the English countryside. Contrasts this with the formal French garden style, and looks at the great houses whose gardens were worked on by Brown - Longleat, Chatsworth House and Blenheim.

results.title: Canterbury: home of handweaving
results.brief_description: Hand weaving loom and spinning wheel manufacture in a Canterbury workshop. Shows the care and skill used in the production of these machines, each the work of one craftsman. At the Cathedral Weaving Centre, weavers can buy materials and learn the art of making fine hand-woven.

results.title: Canine eyes for the blind
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Film Enterprises and Three Crown
results.brief_description: Deals with seeing-eye dogs, describing their use as guides for the blind, and how they are trained and selected. Points out that German Shepherd dogs usually make the best guide. Before training commences the dogs are checked for medical fitness and suitability and introduced to a normal domestic environment. They must undergo exacting tests with blindfolded instructors in city traffic; finally both dog and owner are taught to work together at the training centre.

results.title: Cancer immunology
results.brief_description: Are there truly present, on the cancer cell, antigens different from those in the normal cell, i.e.cancer- specific antigens? If present, how can they be demonstrated? Moreover, through what immunologic mechanisms, and by what factors released from the host, are cancer cells destroyed? This film attempts to answer some of these questions.

results.title: Cancer by the carton
results.creator_credit: Harry R Smith, Leston Post and International Temperance Association
results.brief_description: The relationship between cigarette-smoking and lung cancer. Leading US surgeons and health authorities emphasise the parallel between increased smoking in recent decades and higher incidence of lung cancer. Also stressed is the shorter life of cigarette-smokers. The film dramatizes the story of a (fictitious) editor, who is trying to persuade the Board of a US magazine to publish the facts on cancer. Includes scenes of an actual lung operation, and of the diseased lung after removal.

results.title: Canada's Provinces and people
results.brief_description: Canada, a country with a great variety of landforms and people of many ethnic backgrounds, is emerging as a leader in world trade and has become one of the most prosperous nations of the world. Emphasises the relation of Canada’s natural resources to the lives of the people. Individual regions are mapped with their primary industries.

results.title: Canada's prairie Provinces
results.brief_description: A revealing look at Canada’s heartland. Traditional occupations of wheat farming, cattle raising and lumbering are shown with new occupations created by technology. Harnessing of rivers has brought irrigation and electric power for manufacturing. New industries plus discovery of oil, uranium and other minerals are changing life in the Prairie Provinces.

results.title: Canada's Pacific Province and northland
results.brief_description: Highlights the Pacific Province and northern lands of Canada - British Columbia, the Yukon Territory and the North-west Territories, their historical development and the backgrounds of their people. The land, climate, natural resources and the importance of farming, fishing and lumbering are shown.

results.title: Canada's central Provinces
results.brief_description: This film explores Canada’s most industrialised and mechanised provinces: the variety of geographic regions, the people involved in various farming and industrial activities and life in the major cities. The early history is traced and the contrast between French-influenced Quebec and British-influenced Ontario is highlighted.

results.title: Canada's Atlantic Provinces
results.brief_description: Surrounded by the ocean, dotted with inland lakes and rivers, water plays a major role in the four provinces of New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland, whose inhabitants are mainly of French and British origin. Many of the people continue to lead isolated lives adequately supporting themselves by farming, fishing and lumbering.
